channel.title: Remembrance day
channel.description: So remembrance day is coming up (Canada), and at school we always have our moment of silence during a remembrance day assembly, helps to remind twats. Everything sounds good with that right? Well this year we have a few Americans who wouldn't pay their respect during the moment of silence, nor would they even put on the poppy because of the simple fact that they're American. They said because it wasn't their fault our soldiers died. What the fuck is wrong with people? They live in Canada, our soldiers died so they could live here freely. We even took in Americans in times of war, yet these ingrates wouldn't even wear the poppy for even the duration of the assembly. I know you don't need to wear the poppy to pay respect, but think as a war vet. It must be nice to see everyone publicly acknowledging their sacrifice. Discuss.

item.title: Remembrance day
item.dc:creator: @Squigglyo Squigglyo
item.description:
@Squigglyo wrote:

customs? Yes

Respecting people? No

If i enter a church must i pay God respect? Its frowned upon if i dont, but i dont have too
If i enter Hiroshima should i pay respects to the people that got bombed? It would be nice, but i sure as hell dont have too
If i enter a country that my country fought against, should i pay my respects? Hell no

If i enter a friendly country, should i pay respects to the friendly soldies that died for theres, and quite possibly my country? Not really

If its rememberance day, should i pay respect to the soldiers that fell to protect the country i call home? NO

It would sure be nice if i payd my respects to those people, but i dont have too. I understand what they did, hell i may even actualy respect a select few of them. But being forced to pay respects, or frowned upon if you dont completly destroys the point that these men fought and died for.

If i feel these people deserve my respect then they will get it. But you attempt fo force your respects upon me, then the meaning is gone

item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

[quote=“Squigglyo, post:20, topic:242435”][quote author=TheBeanie link=topic=318782.msg2529028#msg2529028 date=1226360669]

so because someone died for there country… when i visit that country i have to adhere to your rule of respecting them?

I reckon that the people that died didnt die so they could hog a minuit out of my life, they did it so i could have the freedom to decide to ignore them

You just proved how selfish you are… Its all you you you. Not anyone else.

Point is… If it wasnt for the soldiers fighting for our freedom… You and I Might not be here… So you pay your respect by thanking them for giving you life.
[/quote]

that wasnt neccesarily my point of view. but i am a big believer of freedom. No one forces me to do anything i dont want to do. If i believe someone deserved my respect they get it. But i dont go around handing out big baskets of respect just because someone told me too.

There are millions of people that have changed the world for the better and the worst, all of which lead to us being here. None of us would be here today if Hitler hadnt killed all them Jews, but do we thank him for that? Me and you wouldnt be here without it… so why not[/quote]

Any man that has died for another individual or group of people deserves our respect. However, their reasons behind it must be justified. If you come into a country, it’s expected that you adopt their customs (or at least respect) them for the time that you are there.

I had a similar experience where i was on visiting the National Australian War Memorial. There were a few South African children next to me who continued to complain about them having to visit it. They kept saying to the tour guide, “Why should we be here? It has nothing to do with us?”.

Sadly, ignorance spreads if the general population is not educated as to what should be considered correct.
